stories: The aim of this paper is to provide a classification of multilingual andplurilingual electronic lexicographic resources which would enable, on theone hand, the implementation of quantitative and qualitative criteria toproduce a typological taxonomy of lexicographical tools, such as dictionaries,as opposed to platforms and websites and, on the other, the distinction ofmultilingual and plurilingual resources in terms of their larger or lesserprototyping degree. In addition to offering a thorough description of thedifferent resources, this paper also puts forward some parameters andtypological proposals to define and demarcate a number of electronicresources, particularly multilingual dictionaries and portals, while alsooutlining, and even questioning, the object of study of multilingual andplurilingual lexicography.

The aim of this paper is to provide a classification of multilingual and plurilingual electronic lexicographic resources which would enable, on the one hand, the implementation of quantitative and qualitative criteria to produce a typological taxonomy of lexicographical tools, such as dictionaries, as opposed to platforms and websites and, on the other, the distinction of multilingual and plurilingual resources in terms of their larger or lesser prototyping degree. In addition to offering a thorough description of the different resources, this paper also puts forward some parameters and typological proposals to define and demarcate a number of electronic resources, particularly multilingual dictionaries and portals, while also outlining, and even questioning, the object of study of multilingual and plurilingual lexicography.

In order to do so, we will first look at how multilingualism has been defined over time by various authors before moving on to examine what makes up multilingual electronic lexicography before finally looking at how these two concepts can be combined into one coherent whole. We will then see how this new definition can be applied specifically within the context of plurilingual electronic lexicography. Finally, we will explore ways in which this new definition could potentially impact future research within the field of plurilingual electronic lexicography.

It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).

Now that we have established what multilingualism and plurilingualism entail, let us now turn our attention towards examining how these concepts relate specifically to electronic lexicography. As we will see below, there are several different types of electronic lexicography which can be classified according to their degree of multilingualism or plurilingualism. It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).

It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).

It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).

It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).

It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).

It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).

It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).

It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).

It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).

It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).

It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).

It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).

It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).

It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).

It should be noted that although there is no universal agreement amongst scholars regarding exactly what constitutes multilingualism or plurilingualism, most agree that both terms refer to more than just two languages being used simultaneously (e.g., Spolsky 1986). This means that any attempt at creating a clear distinction between these two concepts must take into account not only the number of languages involved but also their relationship to each other (i.e., whether they are complementary or contradictory).

A common approach taken when trying to distinguish between multilingualism and plurilingualism involves looking at whether or not all of the languages spoken by a given individual are acquired through formal education or whether some are acquired informally through exposure to them in everyday life (e.g., Grosjean 1982; Skutnabb-Kangas & Phillipson 1994). Another possibility is to look at whether or not an individual is able to function effectively in all of his or her languages or whether one language takes precedence over others depending on the situation (e.g., Kachru 1985).

Regardless of how multilingualism is defined, however, it is generally agreed upon that it differs from bilingualism in that it involves more than just two languages. Bilingualism, on the other hand, typically refers to the ability to use two languages fluently and interchangeably without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982). Plurilingualism, then, can be seen as a special case of multilingualism wherein an individual is able to function effectively in multiple languages simultaneously without experiencing any significant interference between them (e.g., Grosjean 1982).
